segments.text: You were saying that this chart was reasonably accurate.
I think all those charts are as good as you can put them together.
Okay, so those could go in the front of the interviews then, and that would explain about where we feel like everyone may happen to be.
Now then, the next thing is that you were going to say something about a British team also being involved.
Yes, the British had, and particularly the people from Imperial Chemical Industry and the oil industry of Great Britain, they had teams over there too.
Now, these were headed, if I remember, by Gordon.
Kenneth Gordon, who was a very good personal friend of mine.
He loved sailing, and I was doing a lot of sailing about that time.
And Kenneth Gordon and I became very good close friends, as a matter of fact.
And Kenneth Gordon was the man who first allowed us to go through Imperial Comfort Industries' coal hydrogenation plant when Storch and I went over there.
I see.
And there was another man by the name of Halroyd.
I've forgotten Halroyd's first name.
H.H.
Storch.
Anyway, Howell Road was a very important contributor to the knowledge in the British team.
The British teams did not have as many people over there as we did, but I bet they had half as many.
They were very, very knowledgeable people, too.
Mr. Gordon put out the Gordon Report.
which the British government then published about perhaps the size of it.
I think I have a copy of that here.
That's a very high item.
That took us months to locate.
Did it?
Oh, these things are very difficult.
I think I have a copy of Kenneth's report.
I have some of the copies of the old chaos reports and so on, so the ones I'm particularly interested in.
Of course, of course.
I couldn't keep them all.
I had a whole wall covered with these things, but as the years went by, I had to discard some of them, and I did.
Now, two or three other things came along of importance with this.

As we investigated both the fissure tropes and the coal hydrogenation processes and became acquainted with the German people who were the top echelon in the development of the processes and the operation of the plants and so on and so forth,
particularly the group in the Bureau of Mines became very much interested in bringing German scientists back to this country.
And the oil companies were interested too.
And so the Army at that time was developing a means whereby we could contract with those people to bring them over to this country.
So we brought over
Donath, who was one of the best chemists in the coal hydrogenation work.
And he was Pierre's assistant.
And we brought over Alberts, who was Alberts and Pickler, who were very, Alberts had done most of the work in developing the plants, the Fischer-Tropsch plants in Germany.
Pickler had done a lot of the research work in Germany.
We brought over Hoobman, who was one of their best gasification people.
And I guess we brought over four or five other people, and some of them whose names have sort of escaped my memory.
We're talking about something that happened 20 or 25 years ago, so they've sort of escaped my mind.
I can't even recall what I had for breakfast this morning.
Yes.
But anyway, and one of the things that you might be interested in is that
The German technology for the production of oxygen in large quantities for these plants was... Hydrogen.
Oxygen.
For gasification and things like that was considerably advanced over our own technology.
And after I got back and we began to develop Louisiana, Missouri, we wanted an oxygen plant to...
run our copper-stoxic gasifier.
Now, this is a way of making hydrogen, but you use oxygen along the way.
And we had, in our work over there, had come on, had investigated a small oxygen plant, about a ton an hour plant.
It was at Hakes, H-O-E-C-H-S-T, I think, outside of Frankfurt.
And we got the idea that maybe the best way for us to get a small oxygen plant over here would be to go over and see if the Germans would pack that up and ship it to us.
And Joe Daugherty, who was then my assistant in synthetic fuels, went over there, and he talked to Clay about it.
And Clay said, well, he thought they could get it arranged.
Remember, General Clay was in charge of the occupation for some time after Lucius Clay.
I was trying to remember his first name.
You've got it, Lucius Clay.
And the Germans agreed with that.
They were not using the plant, and they packed it up very beautifully and numbered all the parts and gave us the drawings and so on and so forth.
And while Joe Doherty was over there getting this all arranged, I got the idea, well, maybe we ought to bring back a few Germans to help us put the plant together.
So we got two of the workmen who were skilled in building these plants and two of the engineers, and we brought them over here.
And we erected the plant in Louisiana, Missouri.
And it worked beautifully.
It was always a joy to me that we, the plant was not in use, and it was something that we could use very much.
And we did run it for months at Louisiana, Missouri.
And in a way, I think that started a much larger expansion of the volume oxygen production here in the United States.
The Germans were way ahead of us on that.
on that fitness.
Now, the Louisiana, Missouri plant was taken over by Bechtel, or didn't Bechtel have a hand in... No, Bechtel built the Louisiana, Missouri plant, of course.
I see, I see.
Now, let me get at what happened in the Jura mines after this investigation.
See, this was all going on just as we were beginning to start our investigation on a bigger scale on synthetic fuels as a result of the act of Congress, the Synthetic Liquid Fuel Act.
And so we were very anxious, of course, to bring back as much information about how to build a fair-sized coal hydrogenation and fisheries plant as we possibly could.
So these reports had specific and direct and immediate application as soon as we got back to the United States, as far as our own work at Louisiana, Missouri was concerned.
So what we set out to do at Louisiana, Missouri, was to design a coal hydrogenation plant
fairly much after the German technology, to produce about 200 barrels a day and to test American coals in this coal-hygienation plant.
And we hired the Bechtel Corporation as the engineering corporation who would help assist us in designing and building this plant.
Now, this is where Bechtel came into the picture.
And as I told you, we had brought back several of the German engineers.
including Donath.
And they worked at Louisiana, Missouri with Bechtel and with our engineers to design this plant.
And we ran that plant then through the late 40s and through the early 50s, testing about five or six American coals in it and getting the operation of the plant smoothed out and so on and so forth.
And as a matter of fact,

I think one of the first uses for synthetic fuels is that on our inauguration program for that plant, I'm not sure it was the inauguration program or whether it was somewhat later, we ran a diesel engine train from St. Louis to Louisiana, Missouri with a lot of oil people on synthetic fuel that was pulled out there by synthetic fuels.
That plant ran until about 1953.
We also build a fissure tropics plant out there.
Now, the fissure tropics, I don't know whether you're familiar with thinking about this process or not, but the fissure tropics is a two-step process.
You make CO and hydrogen from coal with steam, coal, and oxygen.
And then the CO and hydrogen are combined to make liquid fuels.
You probably will get yourself saturated in this technology, even though you're a historian before you're through with this thing.
And we build about 50 barrel a day of fissure tropics plants out there.
Now, this has to be done under very high pressure at very high temperatures.
Well, the coal hydrogenation plant is a very high pressure plant running anywhere from, I'd say, about 3,000 to 10,000 pounds per square inch.
The fissure tropics is not a high pressure plant.
Your highest pressures are around 500 pounds per square inch.
But very high temperature as well.
Not neither is it what we call extremely high temperature.
The fasciotropes plant would run around, oh, I'd say around 600, 700 degrees Fahrenheit, and the co-hygienation plants around 900 degrees Fahrenheit.
Now, those are not real high temperatures.
Those are temperatures that go a day.
As far as catalysts, did you require a cobalt or a nickel-thiesel or a thorium?
The catalyst picture is very complex.
You can...
cobalt, molybdenum, tungsten, thorium, things like that, are excellent catalysts for coal hydrogenation.
Strike that thorium out, that's a catalyst.
But iron is a catalyst for coal hydrogenation.
So there's a lot of catalysts.
And the coal hydrogenation process, you really also have a two-step process in that you hydrogenate the coal
in one step.
And this produces some distillable oils that are comparable to a synthetic crude, but it also produces some heavy oils.
And you recycle the heavy oils back through the process.
Now, in Germany, in general, all of this distillable oil was rehydrogenated again to make final products.

In the Fischer-Tropsch process, after you have made the gases C on hydrogen and then made your gasoline, your final step is usually simply a refining or distillation step to separate it out into the various products that you want.
Now, the Fischer-Tropsch process will make anything from a very light gasoline-like product to a fairly heavy oil.
The coal hydrogenation will also make light products to heavy products, but it also makes a good high-octane gasoline.
The aromatic content, which comes from the coal itself, the coal structure, tends to make a better product for gasoline than the Fischer-Tropsch product does.
The Fischer-Tropsch product is better for such oils as diesel oils and things of that nature.
Now, we came back to Louisiana, Missouri with all of this data and built the plants and ultimately ran the plants for a number of years.
By this time, we were getting into the early 1950s.
We hired, oh, by the way, I should mention to you that on the fish tropes plant at Louisiana, Missouri, the design and construction of that plant was by Coppers and Company of this country.
Of this country?
Yeah, this country.
We brought Totsik over here to help us design and build and erect the Totsik gas fire.
Now, he was from Coppers of Germany.
Okay.
I didn't know that we had an American...
Well, coppers of this kind, you must not say that.
So they're a big company.
As a historian, I wouldn't.
Yes, coppers of this kind.
And both Bechtel and coppers did a wonderful job for us.
They were tremendously interested in the whole project, and they did a wonderful job for us.
Now, let me go on with this a little bit more.
Because we're going to come to the meat of this thing right now.
At the end of the late 40s and early 50s, we had quite a lot of data and knew quite a lot about these operations.
And so the next thing was, let's find out what the economics is.
I mean, after all, it does come down to $1.
and sense propositions.
And this is the problem that always faces synthetic fuels or synthetic gas.
As you know, you don't want to pay $4 a thousand for the gas going into your house.
I mean, your heating bill goes from $40 a month to $200 a month, and you're unhappy as hell, if I may use that expression on your record.
And the same thing is true of liquid fuels.
I mean, if you have to have a plant which is enormously capital costly and which takes a lot of men to run and everything, you're going to have a very expensive product.
So we hired Bechtel, and working with our own engineers, we sat down and
made a study of what we could conceive in 1950 to be the best and the most economical coal hydrogenation plant we could build.
And whereas at that time a refinery ran around $1,000 to $2,000 per barrel per day of production, these plants turned out to be about $12,000 or $13,000 per barrel per day of production.

And the cost of the product at the refinery, gasoline at the refinery, was then selling for about 10 or 11 cents a gallon, and the cost of gasoline from a coal hydrogenation plant was in the order of 30 or 35 cents a gallon.
So... That's the bottom line.
That's the bottom line, and so you had to say to yourself, but this didn't look like a very economic process.
And this was the best we could conceive.
We had, in fact,
increased the thermal efficiency of the process.
The German thermal efficiency was very, very low.
It was around 30%.
And we had increased the thermal efficiency to an estimated 55% based on the heat and the coal.
And this probably was the best we could conceive.
We worked with the Copper's Company in developing a similar set of figures for fish troughs.
And then later on, the National Petroleum Council wanted to enter into those studies, and we ran cooperative studies.
And all of these studies came up with a no-go proposition as far as
Competitive prices were at that time.
My next question was going to be, or my original question was going to be, why did the program come to an end?
Let me go on.
That is one reason why it came to an end.
Economics.
But there's another reason.
And
The other reason has nothing to do with synthetic fuel technology.
And I think you know what the other reason is.
During the period of the 30s and 40s, and particularly after World War II, there was a greatly increased exploratory effort in the Middle East.
Although everybody knew there was a lot of oil in the Middle East, I don't think anybody appreciated how much oil and how cheaply oil could be produced in the Middle East.
And Kuwait and Saudi Arabia and Iran and the surrounding countries, many of them, were found to be literally afloat on oil.
And reserves were built up by the 60s in the order of hundreds of billions of barrels.
And oil costs in those countries were well below a dollar a barrel.
And shipping costs to this country were less than a dollar a barrel.
So in any event, you were talking about oil in this country that was only worth $2 a barrel if it was competing with foreign oil, and maybe $3 a barrel if it was competing with American oil.
Would you shut off the recording?
Shut off, right there.
Okay, okay.
Well, I think that, in essence, brings us through.
In an hour and a half, we've brought you through pretty well a...
Oh, but I have some questions.
The plants, then, I take it, were disassembled.
The Louisiana, Missouri plant ran, I think, through about 1953 or 1954.
And then I believe that Hercules Powder Company
bought the site back from the government or acquired the site from the government.
I believe that plant was disassembled, both the fissure trope and the coal hydrogenation.
That's what I thought.
Now, I wonder what happened to the records of those plants.
Shouldn't they be filed someplace?
I heard about eight months ago a group of engineers from the floor company
were here investigating not the history but the technology of coal hydrogenation and fisheries operations.
And they told me that those records from those plants had all been filed at Brewston and then ultimately had been shipped to Morgantown, West Virginia.
but that they had gone to Morgantown, West Virginia, and somebody down there discovering all these files had not been in use for years and years and years had destroyed the files.
That was shortly before they got there.
So I don't know.
I don't know whether this is true or not, but at least the Floor Corporation thought it was true.
What corporation was this, then?
The Floor Corporation.
They're in Los Angeles, California.
Okay, that's F-L-O-O-R?
F-L-U-O-R. F-L-U-O-R. Yeah, they're well-known.
That's a big engineering company.
They're building a fish trough plant over for South Africa.
Okay, right.
That's what I thought.
I wanted to make sure I got that.
Now, isn't Kubi at Morgantown?
Wayne Kuby, also in Chemical Engineering.
He certainly may be, but the people I know, they're practically all retired.
Jim McGee and Sid Cattell and those people are all retired.
They're getting to my age, and they're lazier than I am, I think.
Now, were there any studies, reprints?
No.
Did you publish any studies from the plant's activities?
Oh, there's an enormous amount of publications.
Okay.
Those, you see those books there.
You should have.
Right.
That's not one.
Is this the annual report?
Those are the annual reports.
That's what comes out of those plants right there.
And I think they ran through 54 maybe or 55.
So those are all available.
Okay.
And then there were a lot of journal articles published, and there were separateyou ought to getthe Bureau of Mines has a library in there.
Whatever publication they've ever put out, it was in the Department of Interior.
And if you can't find it in the Department of Interior, I think they have a very complete library still out here on the campus at their college.
You know, there's the Bureau of Mines station out there.
Here?
I didn't know that.
Yeah, it's just up the hill from us, about half a mile, a quarter of a mile.
And they have a complete library.
But if you go down to the Department of Interior, they have a complete, even a more complete library.
No short pictures of the plant and everything else, no.
Because we haven't, I haven't seen any of these, no references to these.
You've never seen them?
No, never.
No, all that work was well documented.
Okay, now it, now the Germans who came over and assembled the plants, did they stay here or did they return to Germany?
A fair share of them stayed here.
Donath was with us at Louisiana, Missouri, up through the days of the operation of the plant.
He left Louisiana, Missouri, and went with the coppers company.
He had two sons of both, I believe, who graduated from MIT and did very well in their schoolwork.
Donath then retired and went out to the Virgin Islands, St. Thomas, I believe.
And he may still be living, but I'm not absolutely sure of that.
Alberts, I believe, also joined Blaunox, which later became Gravo Company.
And I believe Alberts is here, if he's still living.
I can't tell you all these things.
And, uh, Hoobman, uh, Hoobman, I believe, uh, went back to Germany.
He headed the Lurgy organization, uh, back in Germany after he went back.
I believe he's dead now.
I'm not sure of this.
Uh, I have a little problem.
I don't know what happened to Pickler.
I really don't know any, uh, what happened to Pickler.
I have a slight historical problem with the bring you over to the German war scientists.
It seems to me that, at least in disciplines other than oil, in your field, in chemistry, Americans were making plans to bring the German scientists back as early as 1944.
Is that not correct?
No, I'm sure they weren't.
Because I think Operation Paperclip, as it was called... Yeah, that's what's right.
Okay.
I think those guys were talking about which scientists they wanted and which scientists they didn't want by the middle of 1944.
Well, it may have been earlier than that.
I don't know.
Okay.
We brought them back...
I would say that most of them were on their way here in 545.
I'm far from sure that we were the earliest team over there, too.
I'm sure that some of the explosive teams and people like that were over there earlier than we were.
Quite frankly, that's what I thought you were doing over there.
When I saw explosives, I thought you were there with heavy water.
It would make sense.
No, no, we had nothing to do with that.
Okay, the...
Was there any informal or formal contact among the members of TOM and the German scientists after the plants were disassembled?
I mean, just what I'm trying to find out, and the question is poorly phrased, does the issue of synthetic oil just simply drop off the board, so to speak?
No, when we came back, we had...
Oh, I would say three or four or five meetings of not necessarily, certainly not all of the team, but various sections of the team came to meetings in Washington and so on and so forth.
And these were meetings that Miller was very active in, and getting the reports organized and getting a spotlight.
But I'd say within a year after we got back, the thing was pretty well, in a sense.
Was it because President Truman had done away with the Petroleum Administration for War?
the war administration for petroleum, or was it the fact perhaps that people were no longer interested in secrets and documents and...
I think the latter.
I see.
I think...
But this is a wartime activity.
I think industry had now had available most of the information they wanted about the German technology.
Good.
And...
That's better, isn't it?
Yes, I think maybe it'll pick it up slightly better.
I mean, it'll take a hum out of it.

And as far as we in the Bureau of Mines are concerned, we had gathered most information we wanted about their synthetic fuel work and about their fissure trucks work and had used it in our plants and our laboratories.
And so I think it just naturally tapered off rather.
Plus the fact that it wasn't proven to be economical at the moment.
It wasn't proving to be economical, we see what we see.
And now, may I go on just to... Sure, we will.
The only reason we're questioning is some things we won't put in right here in the story.
This... After the price of oil began to rise,
I would say in the middle and late 60s, we sensed again that it was probable that the world as a whole was going to be interested in converting coal to fuels.
And I think everybody thought that
by the time oil reached $8 to $9 a barrel, that then synthetic fuel plants would become an economic possibility.
Now, by we, do you mean the Bureau of Mines again?
Well, I think not only the Bureau of Mines.
I left the Bureau of Mines in 1953.
That's what I thought.
And so this was not only the Bureau of Mines.
I think the Bureau of Mines had the same feeling
But I talked to oil people.
At that time, I was a member of a number of committees of the National Academy of Science.
And we had began to review these processes.
And I think both the oil people and the Bureau of Mines and people like myself began to feel, well, synthetic fuels was coming back into the picture.
But two things happened, which were
I guess it's fair to say, quite discouraging.
One was that while IRDA had spent a lot of money on investigating the technology, and this had been over a period of four or five years,
We didn't have any material breakthrough in the technology.
We were still following the German patterns in both the coal hydrogenation work and the Fischer-Trumpsch work.
And without a material breakthrough, we still faced a highly complex and costly plan.
And the next thing that began to happen is that there were enormous inflation of construction costs.
And then the third thing that began to happen is there was an enormous inflation in coal costs.
So when you ultimately got through, you faced the fact that even though we knew better catalysts, and even though we

knew that we could operate at lower pressures, and even though we had cut the retention times to a minor extent, we still faced oil that was probably, at the minimum, $20 a barrel, and probably might easily go to $30 a barrel.
And this was in face of the fact that we are now importing oil at $12 or $14 a barrel, and we were still
behind the economic eight ball.
